raw_response: {"answer_index": 1, "answer_text": "McCune-Albright syndrome", "confidence": 9, "reasoning": "This case presents the classic triad of McCune-Albright syndrome: (1) café-au-lait spots (irregular brown macules), (2) precocious puberty (early breast development in a 7-year-old), and (3) fibrous dysplasia of bone (which causes hypophosphatemia due to renal phosphate wasting). The red striae and plethoric cheeks suggest Cushing's syndrome, which can occur in McCune-Albright due to autonomous adrenal hyperfunction. Paget's disease is incorrect as it occurs in elderly patients and doesn't explain precocious puberty or café-au-lait spots. Cushing's disease alone doesn't explain the café-au-lait spots or hypophosphatemia. Hypopituitarism would not cause precocious puberty.", "evidence_quality": "normal"}
